mainmatter.p: Given a discrete vector field, the discrete version of field lines is defined as a sequence of cells alternating between degree p and (p-1) starting and ending with lower-degree cells, with a few requirements.

ul.li: When the degree increases, the two cells must occur as a vector in the DVF.
When the degree decreases, the degree (p-1) cell must be a (possible non-regular) face of the degree p cell.
Two degree (p-1) cells separated by a degree p cell must not be the same.

mainmatter.p: A discrete vector field (DVF) on an algebraic cellular complex is given by a collection of pairs of cells ( \sigma , \tau ), where \sigma is a regular face of \tau, standing for a vector pointing from \sigma to \tau, which we will write as \overrightharpoon { \sigma \tau }. We require that every cell appears at most once in these vectors.

A DVF naturally partitions the cells into three kinds: the sources, the targets, and the rest of the cells are called critical cells. This name comes from the analogy to Morse theory. Indeed there is a notion of discrete Morse function.

frontmatter.title: Regular face in an algebraic cellular complex

mainmatter.p: Given an algebraic cellular complex and a cell \sigma, a regular face of \sigma is a cell whose coefficient in d \sigma is \pm 1.

frontmatter.title: Chain reduction generated by a discrete vector field

mainmatter.p: Given an admissible discrete vector field on a algebraic cellular complex (C_k, d), we can generate a chain reduction. It will be computable when the cellular complex is effective.

The DVF partitions the chain groups into a direct sum C_k^{s} \oplus C_k^t \oplus C_k^c, corresponding to source, target and critical cells. We would like to create a reduction to the critical cells only. To do this, we invoke perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction and start with a simpler chain reduction.

Consider the algebraic cellular complex whose chain groups are C_k, but the differential d'( \sigma ) = \pm \tau iff \overrightharpoon { \tau \sigma } is in the vector field, and zero otherwise. The sign is determined as the sign of \tau in d( \sigma ). Hence d' : C_{k+1}^{t} \to C_k^s, and is zero otherwise. Therefore using the characterization of chain reduction as a direct sum with a split exact chain complex, we see that this complex can be reduced to the complex on C_k^p whose differential is identically zero.

Next, we try to perturb d' to d. We need h_{ \rho } \circ (d' - d) to be locally nilpotent, where \rho is the reduction constructed above. h_{ \rho } can be viewed as the inverse of d', as it maps the source cell to the target cell. Expanding the definition, we see that this map transports cells down the discrete field line. Since the vector field is admissible, such a transportation eventually terminates and it becomes zero.
Given a discrete vector field, if is admissible if every field line has finite length.
